Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Some 73% of Democratic registered voters in the Reuters/Ipsos poll said they were more excited about voting in November after Harris entered the race.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Participants in the Reuters/Ipsos poll; relevant to measuring enthusiasm for the election

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: And while a March Reuters/Ipsos poll found that 61% respondents who intended to vote for Biden were doing so mainly to stop Trump, 52% of Harris voters in the August poll were voting to support her as a candidate rather than primarily to oppose Trump.
Unnamed Group of People.Name of Source: Respondents who intended to vote for Biden/Harris voters
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Participants in the Reuters/Ipsos polls; relevant to understanding voter motivations

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Voters picked Trump as having a better approach to managing the U.S. economy, 45% to 36%, a wider margin than Trump had in another Reuters/Ipsos poll this week.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Participants in the Reuters/Ipsos poll; relevant to evaluating economic policy preferences

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Some 41% of voters in the poll - and 70% of Democrats - said they were worried the next president might sign a national ban on abortions.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Participants in the Reuters/Ipsos poll; relevant to understanding concerns about abortion policy

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: 64% (of Trump voters) saying their choice was more motivated by backing Trump than opposing Harris.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Participants in the Reuters/Ipsos poll; relevant to understanding voter motivations

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: Across four Reuters/Ipsos polls conducted in July, Harris had a 9 point lead among women and a 6 point lead among Hispanics.
Document Sources.Source Justification: Previous polls conducted by Reuters/Ipsos; relevant to tracking changes in voter preferences

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: A separate Bloomberg News/Morning Consult poll published later on Thursday showed that Harris was either leading or tied with Trump in each of those states.
Document Sources.Source Justification: External poll published by Bloomberg News/Morning Consult; relevant to comparing electoral prospects

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: 'It's obvious that running against Harris is more challenging for Trump given the shift in these numbers, but it's certainly not insurmountable,'
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Worked on Trump's 2020 campaign; provides expert analysis on campaign dynamics

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: 'We see it in this poll that people are more motivated about the future than the past,'
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Leader of a liberal group focused on women of color in elected office; provides contextual insight

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The new poll, which was conducted in the eight days ended Wednesday and had a 2 percentage point margin of error, showed Harris picking up support among women and Hispanics.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Conducted the poll; provides data for the article's analysis

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The conservative U.S. Supreme Court in 2022 struck down women's national right to abortion.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Relevant to the article's discussion of abortion policy
